prompt.p: A 70-year-old woman is admitted to the Orthopaedic ward for elective arthroplasty. Her blood results reveal a potassium level of 6.7 mmol/l (normal range 3.3â€“4.7 mmol/l). An ECG is performed by the doctor on call, which shows flattening of the P waves, tall tented T waves and wide QRS.
What is the most appropriate immediate management while more senior help is awaited?

choiceInteraction.simpleChoice: Calcium gluconate IV (10 ml of 10% solution)
Dextrose IV (50 ml of 50% dextrose) and insulin (5 U Actrapid)

modalFeedback.p: Option A is Correct. As ECG changes suggestive of hyperkalaemia are present, calcium gluconate must be administered to stabilize the conductive membranes of the myocardium. This is the single life-saving treatment measure. Thereafter and under the supervision of a senior doctor, definitive treatment should be provided to lower the potassium level.
Option B is Incorrect. Calcium resonium is only used as maintenance therapy to keep potassium levels low after emergency treatment.
Option C is Incorrect. A valid emergency treatment to drive potassium into cells, dextrose and insulin should be administered only once cardioprotective calcium gluconate has been initiated.

Option D is Incorrect. Dialysis is the definitive treatment for refractory hyperkalaemia. However, it takes time to set up emergency dialysis and initial cardioprotective measures are indicated immediately.
Option E is Incorrect. A valid emergency treatment to drive potassium into cells, an inhaled beta 2 agonist should be administered only once cardioprotective calcium gluconate has been initiated.
